page.title: 12LOCAL HISTORY IN GRINDLETON
page.content: People have lived in the area for some 5,000 yrs,with a Bronze Age burial mound excavated at Pinder Hill,Wadd'- ton.Major place-names are Old English, Grindleton meaning "The farm by the gravelly stream";Ch'burn"farm by the stream belonging to Ceatta";and Wadd- ton"the estate belonging to Wadda", possibly a Mercian nobleman.At the conquest,all 3 places were held by Anglo-Saxon royalty,Grin'ton and Wadd' -ton by Earl Tostig,King Edward holding Ch'burn.The Duchy of Lancaster held land in Grindleton and Ch'burn from 1311,with Henry 1V staying at Wadd'ton Old Hall,seat of the Tempest family.The stocks and the pinfold surv- ive there, with 15th cent.St.Helen's Church and alms houses of interest. Links with early textiles include flax processing ponds and hand-loom weaver's cottages.
